discoveredAssets: localhost:8080 - GET / - Login page with demo credentials
localhost:8080 - POST /token - Authentication endpoint (OAuth2 form submission)
localhost:8080 - GET /ping - Health check endpoint (JSON response)
localhost:8080 - GET /edit_profile/{company_id} - Profile edit form (requires authentication)
localhost:8080 - POST /edit_profile/{company_id} - Profile update endpoint (requires authentication)
localhost:8080 - GET /docs - Swagger UI API documentation (no auth required)
localhost:8080 - GET /redoc - ReDoc API documentation (no auth required)
localhost:8080 - GET /openapi.json - OpenAPI specification in JSON format (no auth required)

targets.objective: Test authentication endpoint for vulnerabilities: SQL injection, NoSQL injection, brute force bypass, weak credential handling, session fixation, OAuth2 implementation flaws, and default credential exploitation
targets.rationale: Critical authentication endpoint. Accepts username/password submission. Default credentials (demo:demo) displayed on login page. Potential for authentication bypass, credential stuffing, and session manipulation attacks.

targets.objective: Test for mass assignment vulnerability exploitation, privilege escalation (admin field bypass), IDOR/horizontal privilege escalation (access other company profiles), CSRF attacks, and authorization bypass
targets.rationale: CRITICAL: Demonstrated mass assignment vulnerability - is_admin parameter accepted in POST despite being disabled in HTML form. Successfully escalated to admin status. Test if authorization can be bypassed to modify other companies' profiles.

targets.objective: Test for IDOR/horizontal privilege escalation - attempt to access other company IDs, test with modified tokens/credentials, test authorization checks, test data enumeration
targets.rationale: Parameterized endpoint with company_id. Currently shows authorization error for unauthorized access, but IDOR vulnerability potential exists if authorization checks can be bypassed.

targets.objective: Test login page for XSS, CSRF (no CSRF token observed), credential harvesting, and information disclosure vulnerabilities
targets.rationale: Login page displays default demo credentials in plain text. No CSRF token observed. Test for XSS in username/password fields and CSRF attacks on token endpoint.

targets.objective: Analyze OpenAPI specification for additional endpoints, test documented API schemas for injection vulnerabilities, review authentication mechanisms, and test endpoint combinations
targets.rationale: Public API documentation reveals all endpoints without authentication. Use OpenAPI spec to identify all parameters, request/response formats, and test for schema-based attacks (injection, XXE, etc.).

targets.objective: Test health check endpoint for information disclosure, timing attacks, and authentication bypass attempts
targets.rationale: No authentication required. Accessible endpoint. Test if it reveals system information or can be used for reconnaissance.

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] Mass assignment vulnerability: is_admin parameter in POST /edit_profile/{company_id} accepted and processed despite HTML form field being disabled - successfully escalated user to admin status
[CRITICAL] Default demo credentials disclosed: Username 'demo' and password 'demo' displayed on login page in plain text
[HIGH] IDOR vulnerability potential: /company/{company_id}/jobs endpoint requires company_id parameter - authorization checks observed but potential for bypass
[HIGH] IDOR vulnerability potential: /edit_profile/{company_id} endpoint allows access to other company profiles with proper authorization; test if authorization can be bypassed
[MEDIUM] No CSRF protection observed: Login form and profile update POST lack CSRF tokens - vulnerable to cross-site request forgery
[MEDIUM] API documentation publicly accessible: /docs, /redoc, and /openapi.json endpoints expose full API specification without authentication - aids attacker reconnaissance
[MEDIUM] Weak authentication mechanism: Cookie-based Bearer token appears to be simple base64 encoded (token 'MQ==' decodes to '1'), suggesting weak token generation
[LOW] No exposed sensitive files: .git, .env, and other backup files not accessible
[LOW] Health check endpoint (/ping) accessible without authentication - useful for reconnaissance
